title: Contested Borders: Non-governmental public action and the technologies of the war on terror
abstractText:
This research aims to explore and analyse the implications of post 9/11 data-led border security for the agenda and scope of non-governmental public action. The specific objectives are to -

  • Analyse the effects of new technologies of border security on non-governmental public activity around questions of civil liberties, surveillance and privacy, biometrics and immigration
  • Advance theoretical understanding of the politics of dissent and resistance, particularly knowledge of the relationships between ‘governmental’ regimes of security and apparently ‘non-governmental’ domains of public action;
  • Generate new empirical material detailing the diverse strategies and tactics of a range of groups organising to contest new border governance;
  • Identify the emerging themes and issues that cut across different modes of NGPA, in order that actors may more effectively influence agendas and outcomes. 

The research contributes to the programme objective of building theory in relation to NGPA. Specifically, Contested Borders will advance social science knowledge of what non-governmental action means in the context of wider global processes of governing within the war on terror.
